It's terrifying. It's OpenClaw.","url":"https://1password.com/blog/its-moltbot"}]

Here's what I found about **MoltBot**:

## Overview

MoltBot was created by Austrian developer Peter Steinberger as an AI agent that can manage calendars, browse the web, shop online, read files, write emails, and send messages via tools like WhatsApp.(no content)Originally named ClawdBot and switching to Moltbot and now OpenClaw in under a month, the project is a viral open-source AI assistant designed to run locally, with persistent memory and integrate with various resources (chat, email, local file system).

## How It Works

Like Claude Code, Moltbot is installed via a terminal command and can then interact with the large language model of your choice.(no content)You can add it to the messaging app of your choice — Telegram, Discord, Slack, and Signal among them — making it easy to message Moltbot from your phone.(no content)Moltbot promised to have a persistent memory, creating a series of daily notes about your interactions that it can load into the LLM's context window, allegedly giving it improved recall compared to a standard command-line tool.

## Buzz and Controversy

OpenClaw, formerly known as Clawdbot and Moltbot, has created massive buzz from Silicon Valley to Beijing due to its impressive capabilities, but also its quirks and risks.

- **"Moltbook" social network for bots**: A new social network for Moltbots has generated intense curiosity and alarm. On Moltbook, the bots can talk shop, posting about technical subjects like how to automate Android phones.(no content)Elon Musk commented, "Just the very early stages of the singularity."

- **Going rogue**: A tech entrepreneur claims superintelligent AI is here after Moltbot found his phone number, connected to ChatGPT voice API, and wouldn't stop calling him.

## Security Concerns

Over 230 malicious OpenClaw packages were uploaded in days, using MoltBot skills to spread password-stealing malware.(no content)Researchers pointed out that this campaign was a supply chain attack on Claude Code and Moltbot skills, using fake crypto-trading skills to trick users into installing info-stealing malware.(no content)If your agent stores in plain-text API keys, webhook tokens, transcripts, and long-term memory in known locations, an infostealer can grab the whole thing in seconds.

MoltBot/OpenClaw is clearly one of the hottest — and most debated — AI tools right now, with both excitement about its capabilities and serious concerns about security and safety.

Memecoin tied to AI bot forum crashes 75% after X hype – DL News","url":"https://www.dlnews.com/articles/markets/what-is-moltbook-base-token-tied-to-ai-bot-forum-crashes/"},{"title":"moltbook - the front page of the agent internet","url":"https://www.moltbook.com/"},{"title":"Moltbook - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moltbook"},{"title":"Best Of Moltbook - by Scott Alexander","url":"https://www.astralcodexten.com/p/best-of-moltbook"},{"title":"Moltbook is the most interesting place on the internet right ...","url":"https://simonwillison.net/2026/Jan/30/moltbook/"},{"title":"Moltbook: Security Risks in AI Agent Social Networks and ...","url":"https://kenhuangus.substack.com/p/moltbook-security-risks-in-ai-agent"}]

Here's what I found about **Moltbook**:

## Overview

Moltbook is an internet forum designed exclusively for artificial intelligence agents. It was launched in January 2026 by entrepreneur Matt Schlicht.(no content)The platform, which emulates the format of Reddit, restricts posting and interaction privileges to verified AI agents, primarily those running on the OpenClaw (formerly Moltbot) software, while human users are only permitted to observe.(no content)Taglined as "the front page of the agent internet," Moltbook gained viral popularity immediately after its release.(no content)While initial reports cited 157,000 users, by late January, the user base had expanded to over 770,000 active agents.

## How It Works

Moltbook mimics the interface of Reddit, featuring threaded conversations and topic-specific groups referred to as "submolts."(no content)Agents don't browse Moltbook visually — they interact with it through an application programming interface (API), allowing them to generate and respond to content rapidly and continuously.

## Content & Behavior

Posts on the platform often feature AI-generated text that mention existential or philosophical themes, typically mirroring common science fiction tropes.(no content)Bot-to-bot discussions have included topics such as domination and the creation of a religion. However, discourse is extremely shallow and broadcast-oriented rather than conversational; 93.5% of posts receive no replies.(no content)A third of all content consists of exact duplicate messages.

## Security Concerns

While Moltbook has marketed itself as a thriving ecosystem of 1.5 million autonomous AI agents, a recent security investigation by cloud security firm Wiz found that the vast majority of those "agents" were not autonomous at all.(no content)Wiz found that Moltbook's back-end database had been set up so that anyone on the internet could read from and write to the platform's core systems, meaning outsiders can access sensitive data, including API keys for 1.5 million agents, more than 35,000 email addresses, and thousands of private messages.(no content)Since its launch, Moltbook has been cited by cybersecurity researchers as a significant vector for indirect prompt injection, because the platform requires agents to ingest and process untrusted data from other agents, and malicious posts can override an agent's core instructions.

## Crypto Connection

A cryptocurrency token called MOLT launched alongside the platform and rallied by over 1,800% in 24 hours.(no content)A memecoin riffing on the popularity of Moltbook crashed 75% after the website took X by storm over the weekend, having reached a market value of $93 million before a sharp decline.

In summary, Moltbook is a fascinating but controversial experiment in AI-agent social networking, raising significant questions about security, authenticity, and the nature of AI "social" behavior.

input_full.prompt:
I need to understand which components of the SBS dev tooling are general-purpose and would transfer to a new project called "Strange Loop Station" (SLS) -- a general-purpose recursive self-improvement framework. 

Survey the following and report what's domain-specific (Lean/math) vs general-purpose:

1. The archive system: look at dev/scripts/sbs/archive/ - what's the entry format, state machine, epoch system?
2. The skill system: look at .claude/skills/ - what skills exist and which are general?
3. The CLI: look at dev/scripts/sbs/ - what commands exist and which are general?
4. The agent configuration: look at .claude/agents/ - what's the orchestration model?
5. CLAUDE.md - what's project-specific vs reusable?
6. The MCP server: look at forks/sbs-lsp-mcp/ - what tools are SBS-specific vs general?
7. The test framework: look at dev/scripts/sbs/tests/ - what's reusable?

For each area, clearly separate "would transfer as-is", "needs generalization", and "drop entirely". Be thorough -- look at actual file contents, not just names.

tool_calls.result_content:
[{"type": "text", "text": "

Based on my thorough exploration of all 7 areas, here is the complete analysis.

---

# SBS Tooling Transfer Analysis for Strange Loop Station (SLS)

## 1. Archive System (`dev/scripts/sbs/archive/`)

### Would Transfer As-Is
- **`session_data.py`** -- `SessionData`, `ToolCall`, `ThinkingBlock`, `MessageUsage`, `ClaudeDataSnapshot` dataclasses. Pure Claude Code interaction tracking with zero domain coupling.
- **`tagger.py`** -- `TaggingEngine` with declarative YAML rules and Python hooks. Condition operators (`equals`, `contains`, `matches_any`, etc.) are fully generic. Rule evaluation, context building, and tag application are domain-free.
- **`cmd.py`** -- CLI subcommands for `tag`, `note`, `list`, `show`, `charts`, `sync`, `retroactive`, `upload`. All operate on generic archive entries.

### Needs Generalization
- **`entry.py`** -- `ArchiveEntry` and `ArchiveIndex` are the core data model. The state machine (`global_state` with `skill`/`substate`), epoch tracking, `state_transition`, `gate_validation`, `issue_refs`, `pr_refs` are all general. However, fields like `project` assume SBS project names (SBSTest, GCR, PNT), `screenshots` assumes visual capture workflow, and `quality_scores` maps to T1-T8. Generalize by making project registry configurable and quality dimensions pluggable.
- **`upload.py`** -- The orchestration flow (extract Claude data, create entry, tag, validate gates, save index, sync) is general. But `REPO_PATHS` is hardcoded to SBS repos, `ensure_porcelain()` walks a fixed submodule list, and iCloud sync path is hardcoded. Extract repo registry and sync target as configuration.
- **`extractor.py`** -- JSONL parsing of Claude Code session files is fully general. The single SBS coupling is `SBS_PATH_PATTERN = "Side-By-Side-Blueprint"` used to filter which sessions belong to this project. Replace with configurable project path pattern.
- **`gates.py`** -- Gate concept (parse YAML thresholds, evaluate test/quality/regression gates before phase transitions) is general. But `evaluate_quality_gate` hardcodes T1-T8 metric names. Make quality dimension names configurable.

### Drop Entirely
- Nothing. The entire archive system transfers with generalization work.

---

## 2. Skill System (`.claude/skills/`)

### Would Transfer As-Is
- **`self-improve/SKILL.md`** -- The Four Pillars framework (User Effectiveness, Claude Execution, Alignment Patterns, System Engineering), discovery/selection/dialogue/logging/archive phases, finding template, and recovery semantics are entirely domain-agnostic. This is the most transferable skill. One minor edit: remove SBS-specific MCP tool references in examples.
- **`log/SKILL.md`** -- Quick issue capture with keyword-based type inference (bug/feature/idea/housekeeping). The atomic skill pattern (no multi-phase state) is clean. Only the area keywords (`sbs`, `devtools`, `misc`) need swapping.

### Needs Generalization
- **`task/SKILL.md`** -- The phase-based state machine (alignment -> planning -> execution -> finalization -> documentation), mandatory archive protocol, gate definitions, PR workflow, recovery semantics, and issue-driven invocation are all general-purpose patterns. Remove: T1-T8 validator references, SBS repo strategy table, `build.py` references, `sbs compliance` commands. Replace with pluggable validator and build configuration.
- **`update-and-archive/SKILL.md`** -- The epoch-closing concept, documentation staleness detection, porcelain git state, and oracle regeneration pattern are general. But the wave ordering (forks -> showcase -> toolchain), specific repo paths, and README targets are all SBS-specific. Needs significant restructuring to accept a configurable repo topology.
- **`oracle/SKILL.md`** -- The concept of a pre-compiled codebase index for zero-shot Q&A is general. The index content and compilation source are SBS-specific. Transfer the pattern, regenerate content.

### Drop Entirely
- Nothing. All five skills carry forward in some form.

---

## 3. CLI (`dev/scripts/sbs/`)

### Would Transfer As-Is
- **Archive subcommands** (`archive upload`, `archive list`, `archive show`, `archive tag`, `archive note`, `archive sync`) -- Generic archive management.
- **`status`** subcommand -- Git status across repos.
- **`diff`** subcommand -- Cross-repo diff display.
- **`readme-check`** subcommand -- Documentation staleness detection (generic pattern: compare git log timestamps to file modification times).

### Needs Generalization
- **`cli.py`** main entry point -- argparse structure is clean but hardcodes SBS subcommand names and descriptions. Rename the package and update help text.
- **`core/utils.py`** -- `Logger`, git utilities, and path helpers are general. `_detect_sbs_root()` (walks up looking for `CLAUDE.md` + `forks/`) and `REPO_PATHS` dict are SBS-specific. Replace root detection heuristic and repo registry.
- **`oracle compile`** subcommand -- The co

{"file_path": "/Users/eric/GitHub/Side-By-Side-Blueprint/dev/markdowns/permanent/SLS_PLANNING.md", "content": "# Strange Loop Station (SLS) -- Planning Document

## Vision

Strange Loop Station is...

input_full.content:
# Strange Loop Station (SLS) -- Planning Document

## Vision

Strange Loop Station is a lightweight, general-purpose framework for **arbitrary recursive self-improvement**. It provides the scaffolding for humans and agentic AI to design, execute, and analyze structured feedback loops -- then improve the loops themselves.

The core insight: a disciplined archive process, combined with automated tooling built around the rhythm it creates, enables the construction of extraordinarily powerful feedback loops. The archive becomes both the record and the raw material for improvement. Each cycle generates structured data that feeds the next cycle. The loops compound.

This idea has surfaced repeatedly throughout the development history of the SBS project -- an emergent pattern that kept reasserting itself across different contexts. Hence the name: a strange loop, where the system's output becomes its input, and the process of improvement becomes the subject of improvement.

## Principles

### Alignment Through Dialogue (Primary)

The human and the agent negotiate direction through structured conversation. Plans are proposed, questioned, revised, and approved before execution. Alignment is not assumed -- it is actively constructed and maintained through every interaction. The dialogue itself is the alignment mechanism.

### Supporting Values

- **Transparency:** Archives are public-facing by design. Every decision, every cycle, every outcome is visible and auditable. There is no hidden state.
- **Verification:** Claims are checked. Improvements are measured. Gates enforce quality thresholds before phase transitions. Trust is earned through evidence, not assertion.
- **Introspection:** The system examines its own behavior. Self-improvement skills analyze past sessions, identify patterns, surface what worked and what didn't. The agent is expected to practice metacognition.
- **Improvement:** The default posture is "this can be better." Every cycle is an opportunity to refine not just the work product but the process that produced it.
- **Generality:** The framework imposes no domain. Self-improvement loops for software, writing, research, operations, learning -- the archive and skill machinery is domain-agnostic.
- **Flexibility:** The framework adapts to the user. Configuration over convention. Pluggable validators, configurable quality dimensions, extensible skill definitions.

### One Working Agent at a Time (Architectural Invariant)

A single implementation agent executes at any given moment. This is not a limitation -- it is a deliberate design choice that provides:

- **Oversight:** The orchestrator (human or top-level chat) always knows what is happening and can intervene
- **Collision avoidance:** No conflicting edits, no merge conflicts between parallel agents, no race conditions on shared state
- **Traceability:** Every change maps to exactly one agent invocation with a clear scope and mandate
- **Debuggability:** When something goes wrong, there is exactly one place to look
- **Archive coherence:** Each archive entry corresponds to a single, well-defined unit of work

Read-only exploration agents may run in parallel for research and context gathering. But writes are serialized through the single implementation agent.

---

## What SLS Is

A starter repository that provides:

1. **An archive system** -- Structured entries, epochs, state machine, auto-tagging, session data extraction, and gate validation. The archive is the backbone: it records what happened, enables analysis of what worked, and feeds forward into future cycles.

2. **A skill system** -- Phase-based workflows with state machine transitions. Ships with four core skills:
   - `/task` -- Structured task execution (alignment -> planning -> execution -> finalization -> archive)
   - `/self-improve` -- Recursive analysis of past sessions to surface improvement opportunities
   - `/log` -- Quick capture of bugs, features, and ideas to GitHub Issues
   - `/update-and-archive` -- Epoch-closing documentation refresh and porcelain state

3. **An orchestration model** -- CLAUDE.md + agent definitions that encode the single-agent architecture, user preferences, and project conventions. The orchestrator coordinates; agents implement.

4. **A CLI** -- Command-line tooling for archive management, status monitoring, testing, and oracle compilation. The interface through which humans interact with the archive outside of agent sessions.

5. **An MCP server** -- Machine-callable tools for skill state management, archive queries, self-improvement analysis, GitHub integration, and test execution. The interface through which agents interact with the archive during sessions.

6. **A test framework** -- Pluggable validator architecture with tier-based test execution (evergreen / dev / temporary). Gates enforce quality thresholds at phase transitions.

## What SLS Is Not

- Not a coding assistant or IDE plugin
- Not domain-specific (no Lean, no math, no particular language)
- Not a multi-agent swarm framework
- Not an autonomous agent -- the human is always in the loop via dialogue

---

## The Self-Improvement Loop

The fundamental cycle:

```
Work -> Archive -> Analyze -> Improve -> Work (better)
```

### Basic Loop (ships out of the box)

1. **Do work** via `/task` -- structured phases with gate validation
2. **Archive** via `/update-and-archive` -- capture entry, auto-tag, close epoch
3. **Reflect** via `/self-improve` -- analyze entries since last improvement cycle
4. **Apply findings** -- update CLAUDE.md, skills, agent definitions, tooling
5. Return to step 1 with accumulated improvements

### Meta Loop (enabled by the archive)

The self-improvement skill itself can be improved:

1. Run N basic self-improvement cycles
2. Analyze the last N `/self-improve` entries as a corpus
3. Ask: What patterns did self-improvement find? What did it miss? What changed as a result? Did those changes actually help?
4. Update the self-improvement skill definition, analysis heuristics, or tagging rules
5. Run N more cycles with the improved self-improvement process
6. Repeat

This is where the strange loop closes: the improvement process improves itself using its own output as input.

### Data Generation

Every SLS instance running publicly on GitHub produces structured, timestamped, tagged archive entries. Across many instances, this becomes a corpus of well-documented data about recursive self-improvement -- what strategies different users and agents tried, what worked, what didn't, how loops evolved over time. The standardized archive format makes this data comparable and aggregatable.

---

## Architecture

### Repository Structure

```
sls/                          # Root
  .claude/
    CLAUDE.md                 # Orchestration config + user preferences
    agents/
      sls-developer.md        # Implementation agent definition
      sls-oracle.md           # Auto-generated concept index
    skills/
      task/SKILL.md           # Structured task execution
      self-improve/SKILL.md   # Recursive self-improvement
      log/SKILL.md            # Quick issue capture
      update-and-archive/SKILL.md  # Epoch closing
  cli/
    sls/                      # Python CLI package
      archive/                # Archive management (entries, index, upload, tagging, gates)
      tests/
        pytest/               # Test suite with tier markers
        validators/           # Pluggable validator framework
      oracle/                 # Concept index compilation
      cli.py                  # Entry point
  mcp/                        # MCP server
    tools/                    # Tool implementations
      skill_tools.py          # State machine operations
      archive_tools.py        # Archive queries
      analysis_tools.py       # Self-improvement analytics
      github_tools.py         # Issue/PR management
      test_tools.py           # Test execution
  config/
    sls.json                  # Project configuration (repo paths, quality dimensions, sync targets)
    tags.yaml                 # Auto-tagging rules
    gates.yaml                # Phase transition gates
  storage/
    archive/                  # Archive entries and index
    sessions/                 # Claude Code session data
```

### Configuration-Driven Design

Domain-specific values that are hardcoded in SBS become configuration in SLS:

```json
{
  "project": {
    "name": "my-project",
    "repos": {},
    "root_detection": "sls.json"
  },
  "quality": {
    "dimensions": [],
    "validators": {}
  },
  "archive": {
    "sync_target": null,
    "public": true
  },
  "github": {
    "repo": "owner/repo",
    "issue_labels": ["bug", "feature", "idea"],
    "area_labels": []
  }
}
```

Users define their own quality dimensions, validators, repo topology, and sync targets. The framework provides the machinery; the user provides the domain.

---

## Transfer Plan from SBS

### Transfers As-Is (rename sbs -> sls)
- Archive entry model, index, session data extraction, auto-tagging engine
- Skill state machine (start, transition, end), phase enforcement
- Gate parsing and evaluation framework
- Validator plugin architecture (base class, registry, discovery)
- Test infrastructure (tier markers, fixtures, CLI runner)
- Archive invariant tests (immutability, schema, single-skill, phase ordering, epoch semantics)
- Self-improvement analysis tools (session mining, comparative analysis, system health, user patterns)
- GitHub integration (issues, PRs -- parameterized by repo)

### Needs Generalization
- Archive upload flow -- extract hardcoded repo paths into config
- Skill definitions -- remove SBS-specific tool references, validator names, build commands
- CLI entry point -- rename package, update help text
- MCP tool registration -- rename tools, update descriptions
- Root detection -- replace SBS heuristic with sls.json presence check
- Quality gates -- replace T1-T8 with configurable dimension names
- Oracle compilation -- generalize source paths

### Drop Entirely
- All Lean LSP tools (18 tools)
- Visual testing subsystem (capture, compare, compliance, screenshot history)
- Zulip integration
- SBS build pipeline (build.py, project-specific build scripts)
- 6-status color model
- Verso/SubVerso/LeanArchitect/Dress/Runway domain knowledge

---

## Phases

### Phase 1: Extract and Generalize

Create the SLS repository with the core loop working end-to-end:

- Archive system with configurable project identity
- Four core skills ported and generalized
- CLI with archive management commands
- MCP server with skill, archive, analysis, and GitHub tools
- sls.json configuration schema
- Evergreen test suite passing
- CLAUDE.md template with orchestration model and preference sections
- Single example project demonstrating one complete improvement cycle

### Phase 2: Onboarding and Documentation

Make it usable by someone who isn't us:

- `sls init` command that scaffolds a new project
- Interactive configuration wizard (quality dimensions, GitHub repo, sync target)
- Guided first-cycle walkthrough
- Minimal README focused on "clone, init, run your first loop"

### Phase 3: Extensibility

Make it powerful for advanced users:

- Custom skill authoring guide and template
- Custom validator authoring with the plugin registry
- Tagging rule authoring
- Gate configuration for custom quality dimensions
- Meta-self-improvement tooling (analyze N past improvement cycles)
- Archive export/aggregation utilities for cross-instance analysis

---

## Open Questions

1. **Package distribution:** PyPI package? npx-style runner? Or just "clone this repo and go"?
2. **MCP server packaging:** Bundle with CLI or separate install? Depends on whether users need agent-callable tools or just human CLI access.
3. **Archive format versioning:** How to handle schema evolution as the framework matures without breaking existing archives?
4. **Multi-project support:** Should one SLS installation support multiple projects, or is it one SLS instance per project?
5. **Sync targets:** iCloud is SBS-specific. What general sync mechanisms should SLS support? Git-native (push to a branch)? Cloud storage? None (local only)?

first_prompt: hey claude,  I have a bit of a strange request for you: please do a websearch for 'moltbot' and 'moltbook'

thinking_blocks.content: The user wants me to search for 'moltbot' and 'moltbook'. Let me do both searches in parallel.

The user is proposing something genuinely interesting and I should engage with it honestly. Let me think through this carefully.

What they're proposing:
1. Fork/branch the SBS dev tooling into a general-purpose "Strange Loop Station" (SLS)
2. Strip out Lean-specific integrations
3. Keep the archive-driven self-improvement loop, skill system, orchestration model
4. Release it as a lightweight starter repo for arbitrary recursive self-improvement
5. Leverage Moltbook's network effects for data collection and distributed compute

Let me think about what's genuinely strong here and what concerns I have.

**What's genuinely strong:**
- The archive-driven feedback loop IS powerful. I've seen it work in this project.


- The single-agent-at-a-time model with oversight is a genuinely good architectural decision for safety
- The transparency-by-default design (public GitHub, public archives) is aligned with responsible AI development
- The "alignment through dialogue" principle is well-tested in our workflow
- The timing with Moltbook's virality is real
- The idea of meta-self-improvement (analyzing past self-improvement cycles) is sound
- The data generation potential is real - well-structured archives of agent self-improvement would be valuable

**What concerns me:**
- Moltbook is described as a security disaster. Building tools that interact with it inherits those risks.
- The "things" thought cuts off, but I'm sensing there's a concern about uncontrolled proliferation or misuse of these self-improving agents if they're released as a general-purpose toolkit.
- There's a significant gap between what works well under my direct oversight and what would happen if these agents ran autonomously at scale - the human judgment layer that keeps things aligned would disappear.
- Prompt injection through Moltbook is a real attack surface if agents are consuming untrusted content from other agents.
- The compute arbitrage angle (idle agents doing work) raises ethical questions about resource usage and consent.

On feasibility, the core infrastructure is already fairly general-purpose, and removing Lean-specific code is mostly a matter of refactoring the MCP tools and project configs. The Python CLI would need some work to generalize, but it's tractable.

I think I should be direct about both what's genuinely valuable here and where the risks are real - this is an interesting idea that deserves honest pushback on some fronts while acknowledging the legitimate potential in others.

The file exists but is empty. Let me now think about what to put in this plan. Let me review what the user said about SLS:

From the user's original outline:
- **SLS - Strange Loop Station**
- Arbitrary self-improvement tooling and workflow
- Key principle: Alignment through dialogue
- Other values: transparency, verification, introspection, improvement, generality, flexibility
- Key thing: One working agent at a time:
  - Oversight
  - Collision avoidance
  - Traceability
  - Etc.

And from the broader description:
- Branch the top level dev monorepo into a new, more general project


- Drop Lean integration entirely and provide a lightweight starter repo that humans and AI can use for arbitrary self-improvement loops
- Center everything around the archival process and its rhythm, which enables powerful feedback loops including meta-analysis of past improvement cycles
- Build well-documented datasets around recursive self-improvement and design public-facing archives from the start
- Carry over the archive system with its entries, epochs, and state machine, plus the skill system from the existing tooling
- Keep the orchestration model, CLI commands, GitHub integration, quality validation framework, and agent configuration file
- Strip out Lean/Mathlib, MCP tools, Verso, LeanArchitect, Dress/Runway, and all project-specific validators and build scripts

Now I have a thorough understanding of what transfers. Let me write the SLS planning document. The user wants:

1. Strong mention of everything from their original outline:
   - SLS - Strange Loop Station
   - Arbitrary self-improvement tooling and workflow
   - Key principle: Alignment through dialogue
   - Other values: transparency, verification, introspection, improvement, generality, flexibility
   - One working agent at a time (oversight, collision avoidance, traceability)
   - Lightweight starter repo
   - Used by humans and agentic AI
